body:
Hi @Tagar, thank you for your contribution! 

The CI fail looks legit. If you scroll up a bit, you can find maven test failure. They failed because of NPE at `metadataUpdateSpec`.

This is because `metadataUpdateSpec` is mandatory for only Cli Hadoop indexer and should be null for hadoop index task. Please check http://druid.io/docs/latest/ingestion/hadoop.html#ioconfig.

Got it. Thanks @jihoonson 

So this check isn't possible as verify() at 
https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/d5633dd396a5cd16f98cb0e65d24ff5f8d6b33c3/indexing-hadoop/src/main/java/org/apache/druid/indexer/HadoopDruidIndexerConfig.java#L580

doesn't have a way of knowing if this spec is for `Cli Hadoop indexer` or for `hadoop index task` ?

That NPE error I described at https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/issues/6673 is very cryptic and only way to know that `metadataUpdateSpec` was missing is to look at the source code.
Pushed an update.
Hmm, how about checking in `CliInternalHadoopIndexer.getHadoopDruidIndexerConfig()`?
Hi @Tagar, thanks for the contribution! Would you elaborate more on what this script is for?

Some of the use cases 

`./cli.sh tools pull-deps --hadoop-coordinate org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:2.6.5`

or 

`./cli.sh index hadoop hadoopDependencies org.apache.hadoop:hadoop-client:2.6.5 mv-parquet-hadoop.json
`

@jihoonson I will have a look into this.

Thanks.
Yes with latest patch update of jdk1.8 its working fine. I was using 1.8.0_25, x86_64 and now with 1.8.0_202, x86_64 worked fine. Thanks a lot.

@QiuMM if use protobuf parser, KafkaSupervisor discoverTasks  use TaskStorage getActiveTasks() (also should add getActiveTasks(String dataSource) method in TaskStorage and create index in druid_tasks), deserialize task will create Descriptor, may be cause all KafkaSupervisor hang up.
@yunwan thanks for describing your reasoning. LGTM after travis-ci.
If you are running on Yarn you can kill the job with `yarn kill application_id`
This should be closed (was fixed years ago by #3176).
@glasser yup - closing.
I'm not sure, there might be a hadoop setting that kills a map/reduce job if it has more than X% of map or reduce tasks fail. If there isn't then it would be a good setting for hadoop to add :)

Hey Druid community,

Calling for volunteers to help out with this beast of a PR. It would be great if there could be a few more sets of eyes reviewing the changes and mainly providing general feedback on the high-level design and perhaps reviewing critical pieces of the implementation if time permits. The most critical classes to look at would be the ones Josh mentioned in the initial comment, in particular:

```
RecordSupplier + implementations (KafkaRecordSupplier, KinesisRecordSupplier)
SeekableStreamSupervisor + implementations (KafkaSupervisor, KinesisSupervisor)
SeekableStreamIndexTask + implementations (KafkaIndexTask, KinesisIndexTask)
SeekableStreamIndexTaskRunner + implementations (IncrementalPublishingKafkaIndexTaskRunner, KinesisIndexTaskRunner)
```
Maybe other resource test classes should be improved at the same time.

@gianm Thank you for your reply. Don't you think the missing of ability of segment rebalance makes the `RandomBalancerStrategy` incomplete or it is actually no needed for `RandomBalancerStrategy`? 

By the way,  I found a issue using `cachingCostBalancer` described in  #6624. It seems  `cachingCostBalancer` can't perform well in case the new historicals added to a cluster which alreay has mang segment.

I found multiple entries in Historical logs:
>i.d.s.l.SegmentLoaderLocalCacheManager - Segment [***] is different than expected size. Expected [***] found [***]

I summed the difference for one hour it showed that segments occupied ~50MB more than expected which can effectively confuse Coordinator working with sizes from the segment metadata.

I propose to add a dynamic configuration parameter to Coordinator named `segmentCacheReserve` (ie `segmentCacheReserve=50` means 50mb of extra space) which tells Coordinator how much space should be left available at any time on a Historical node.

Hi @leventov
I submitted PR for all the readonly cases #6692

Looking at just the mean topN segment scan times for non-zero reported scan times, this change seems to indicate an approximately 13% improvement in performance for 1.5.0 vs 1.3.0 in a real cluster. Pretty solid and easy upgrade.
I am facing the same issue. Anybody can help please??
@QiuMM yes, sounds great.
Same issue with [Feature scaling](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feature_scaling). Maybe as `druid-stats` extension.
üëç
@drcrallen Nice!  Did you notice any improvement in indexing/merging time ?
@jihoonson @gianm Added tests. Please review.
@egor-ryashin thanks for review
Backport of #6696
Backport of #6694

This is not related to mysql.

@erankor do you have large number of segments in this datasource? I guess the second time to issue this TimeBoundary query would be faster due to the cache. But if you have large number of segments, the segmentMetadata can be always slow, the bottleneck is the broker merging.
@warren288 maybe #6683 also fix this issue. NodeCache is used instead of PathChildrenCache for /druid/annoucements. You can apply this fix in your environment and try it.
@qweed00 sounds the lookup feature can meet your need.
@erankor it sounds either approach produces same number of rows if i understand correctly. less rows, better performance.
Don't think it is a good idea, it is not idempotent. if a realtime node restarts, the data timestamp becomes different. @bhrgv-bolla
This does sound like a good candidate for an aggregator extension.

@kaijianding makes a good point - this strategy won't play well with ingest from Kafka / Kinesis (on replay, the timestamp will change). It might be better to support Kafka's native timestamp field. Currently we don't. There's an issue open for it: #6625

Thanks @kaijianding!
The data source in the first example (timeBoundary) is tiny, the one from the second example (segmentMetadata) is larger -
```
mysql> select count(1) from druid_segments where used and dataSource = 'reach-usage';
+----------+
| count(1) |
+----------+
|       22 |
+----------+

mysql> select count(1) from druid_segments where used and dataSource = 'player-events-historical';
+----------+
| count(1) |
+----------+
|    14740 |
+----------+
```
To make sure I understand what you wrote - in order to answer the second query, the broker has to perform it for all segments and merge the results?
If so, maybe I'll hack it so that it only performs it for the last week or so, the latest schema is probably what I want anyway...
Thanks @kaijianding, yes, the number of rows will be the same.
@erankor yes, for segmentMetadata, the broker will do the merge, and it is slow if you have plenty of segments. A workaround solution is that you can use a smaller interval.
@fanwu72 it sounds like :  select domain, max(val),max(__time) from tbl where domain in ('a.com', 'b.com') and __time >= 1517731200 and __time <= 1517731200 and isp = 'dx' group by domain;

I'm going to close this since it seems to be working in master.

@leventov Currently only broker/coordinator watches all compute nodes, according to #6683 , if a compute node self watches all other compute nodes to find itself (this is how current CuratorDruidNodeDiscoveryProvider works, it watches all compute nodes), the number of watches in zk can grow to huge number.

Is it better to add similar listener mechanism when DruidNodeAnnouncer.announce(DiscoveryDruidNode) is called?

i am also facing same issue.
For resolve issue i am executing following query which too much slow

select __time, value from temp where value in ( select max(value) from temp group by time_foor(__time,'PT14S'))
any progress on this? I'm also having same issue.
@leventov @gianm any other comments? I think it can be merged.

It should be improved in 0.13.0 by #6336.

hi gianm,

I found a bug when I add an allowAll authenticator in the chain Ôºåand I fix it at https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/6708, please review it ! Thanks you very much!

Hi, @dyf6372 . Thanks for your contribution. This problem may appear in all places where the `@Produces` annotation is used. FYI, we'd better fix it at once by adding a `ContainerResponseFilter` subclass instead of modifying the `@Produces` annotation everywhere.
@dyf6372 please add a Checkstyle Regex rule that prohibits adding `@Produces("text/plain")` in the future
@asdf2014 @leventov thanks for the review. I think it makes sense to raise a follow-up pr to apply this to everywhere else. What do you think?

@asdf2014 it seems we can not fix it by adding a `ContainerResponseFilter` since there are no related APIs we can use to do, but I'm not very sure about this. IMO, adding a Checkstyle Regex rule to prohibit `@Produces("text/plain")` would be ok. And for `@Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON)`, I had impression that the default encoding for JSON is UTF-8 and currently I do not observe any encoding problems for JSON.

Certainly, it's better to find a way to fix these encoding problems at once.
@gianm sorry for delay and thanks for review. I'm going to push changes asap.

Can you review and add back the documentation for the extension? Add it to docs/content/development/extensions-core/kinesis-ingestion.md and add references to this page from the extension list.

As part of this, can you make sure that there's a blurb related to the `deaggregate` configuration that in order to use this functionality, they will need to add the aws kinesis lib? Adding a link for where they can fetch it from and where they should put it (in the kinesis extension directory) would be helpful.
@dclim added docs

From https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/pull/4333#discussion_r124079021, the buffer size in these tests have some special meaning. I changed this PR to keep `testGrowing3` but use a smaller buffer for `testGrowing2` which still tests the same bug.

Hi, @jihoonson. Right, this solution is the most simplified. It would be better to use `MediaType.TEXT_PLAIN +"; charset = UTF-8"` instead of `"text / plain"`, which can be declared as a TEXT_PLAIN_UTF8 constant.

> can not fix it by adding a ContainerResponseFilter since there are no related APIs we can use to do

Hi, @QiuMM . Thanks for your comment. I tried program a `MediaTypeFilter` demo, but it's not be tested.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8108788/49561270-59428900-f951-11e8-8908-684259b5f2dc.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8108788/49561378-ec7bbe80-f951-11e8-8b2b-9aa5e6caae20.png)


> And for @Produces(MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON), I had impression that the default encoding for JSON is UTF-8 

For this point, I cannot agree with you :sweat_smile:

@clintropolis here is how things happen.
1. We run realtime jobs on Yarn, and yarn tracks the mem usage including heap, direct memory and native memory which in druid case is mmap.
2. yarn will kill process whose mem usage is much more than it applyed.
3. after druid merges hydrant segments into merged segment, the hydrant segments are mmaped and and the mmap usage is added about the total file size of the hydrant segments which usually hundreds or thousands MB,   AND the added mmap is not released due to the QueryableIndex cann't be closed because the index is still needed by queries.
4. when handoff is slow, the mmap usage will grow to a huge number when the merge process happens many many times. finally Yarn will kill this druid realtime jvm.
5. also, there are many side-effect objects added to heap after merge success, finally OOM happens.

Direct memory is not a problem here,  direct memory is released after each merge success/fail.

The added code in this PR, is to close the QueryableIndex after merge success/fail to explicitly release mmap and other side-effect objects. And these QueryableIndexes are different objects to the ones used by queries, so it's safe.

@asdf2014 currently I do not observe any encoding problems for JSON, but it's fine for me to explicitly 
 set the charset to UTF-8.

In [rfc4627](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4627) section 3, the default encoding of JSON text is UTF-8.
_JSON text SHALL be encoded in Unicode.  The default encoding is UTF-8._ 
_Since the first two characters of a JSON text will always be ASCII characters [RFC0020], it is possible to determine whether an octet stream is UTF-8, UTF-16 (BE or LE), or UTF-32 (BE or LE) by looking at the pattern of nulls in the first four octets._
Since it is possible to determine whether an octet stream is UTF-8, UTF-16, or UTF-32, I'm confused whether to set the charset to UTF-8 for MediaType.APPLICATION_JSON.  Maybe is same to MediaType.TEXT_PLAIN.
Hi, @dyf6372 . Yep, the encoding of JSON should be UTF-8, which is actually an industry standard. However, this is not for Jersey :sweat_smile:

have you solved this problem ? I got the same problem just like yours, and I connected my zookeeper server ls the path '/druid/discovery/druid:overlord', the result is '[]' , it's empty, and I check the log of overlord, there is some error about metadata storage service connection refused, I changed Druid metadata storage type from derby to mysql and restart all components; but the value of '/druid/discovery/druid:overlord'  path is still '[]' ; do you have any idea ? thanks a lot.
@kaijianding i dont think lookup will work, as i need the aggregated result of another row. what i need is a self left join i think. will have to wait until some one implements join support

> @pzhdfy it sounds different with http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-contrib/distinctcount.html which is only for batch ingestion and only for one dimension.
> Could you explain more on how count distinct is done across segments?
> Is global uniq ID global across all segments or just a period like one day(the period you do offline batch ingest)? Is global uniq ID generated on a central server like coordinator, or an algorithm which can ensure id is always different in different segments?

I updated the description, we will add more details later.
I'm trying to figure out why the build gets stuck. Added `WIP` tag.
@VincentNewkirk we sometimes have sporadic travis-ci failures that we are looking at fixing.
I finally changed to allocate buffer on direct memory instead of memory mapped file. For this, I also increased `MaxDirectMemorySize` to 2500m for testing the processing module.

@pdeva when 0.13.0 is released, the docs will be updated and /latest should point to the new docs that describe where to put the mysql driver. You can see the docs here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-druid/blob/master/docs/content/development/extensions-core/mysql.md

Yes, the AWS region property also needs to be applied to the historical configs. The release notes mention adding it to the jvm.config for all Druid services.
It's a great feature. I'm looking forward to it.
@kamaci please merge master into your PR branch to make CI happy
However, not needed, CI passed itself

@gianm I have pushed changes, waiting for code review.

Hi,
Any progress on that ? 
Current druid when using transactions gives me Exception:
```
org.apache.kafka.common.KafkaException: Failed to make progress reading messages at abc_topic=1001264294. Received a non-empty fetch response from the server, but no complete records were found.
```

I think we can update to 2.0.0 now.
Maybe 2.0.0 at this point of time ?
Maybe other places that use ConcurrentSkipListMap can be replaced too.

@QiuMM interesting, thanks. FYI, this PR addresses the same problem: #6327

The project's README (https://github.com/nbronson/snaptree) states that the latest released version is 0.2.

While 35% is spent in the `.get` call is true but most of that time 34% is consumed by the Druid comparator code, so not sure how the  snapTreeMap is going to solve this? can you present some results or benchmarks ?
Plus the last commit in this project is 6 years old and seems that some issues are not fixed https://github.com/nbronson/snaptree/issues @dyf6372 are you aware of other projects using this ?

-1, this change is not needed, did you remember to set the "type" property for allowAll?

e.g. 

```
druid.auth.authenticatorChain=["allowAll", "basic"]
...
druid.auth.authenticator.allowAll.type=allowAll
```

@leventov just like https://github.com/nbronson/snaptree/issues/6 said, v0.2 is not deployed at maven central repo.
@b-slim Cassandra use SnapTreeMap before version 2.1 (https://github.com/apache/cassandra/blob/cassandra-2.0/build.xml).  In version 2.1, it used a custom in-memory BTree to replace SnapTreeMap(https://www.datastax.com/dev/blog/cassandra-2-1-now-over-50-faster).

as per [readme](https://github.com/nbronson/snaptree/blob/master/README#L14) 
```
VERSION 0.2:  Incorporates an important bugfix to isEmpty()
```
 I do not think it is a good idea to use code that is missing important bugfixes for such critical 
section in Druid.
And as you pointed out Cassandra is not using it anymore.

@dyf6372 seems to me the project is not alive and does not have maintainers thus no one to fix bugs.
@jinyangli34 Are you still interested in contributing this PR?
